A Téméraire-class ship of the line that took part in the Glorious First of June. It was captured by the British and accidentally destroyed in a fire at Portsmouth.

Ionic Star was a Blue Star Line cargo ship crashed on the mad wharf sandbank (a mile from Formby point) on a journey from Rio to Liverpool. Her cargo was salvaged and later used as target practice for the Royal Air Force.
A sailing ship wrecked at Scratchell's Bay, near The Needles.
A Spanish cargo ship that was stranded on the south Cornish coast, possibly in Mount's Bay. All her crew were saved and much of the cargo was salvaged.
A German coastal trading vessel captured by the Royal Navy, and bombed by German aircraft off St. Catherine's Point.
A cargo ship that struck a mine southeast of Folkestone.
Sank in Rapparee Cove, North Devon in stormy weather, while carrying prisoners and treasure from the Caribbean island of Saint Lucia.
A cargo ship that struck a mine off Thorpeness.
A steamship that ran aground and broke in two.
A steamship that ran aground and broke in two.
A passenger ship that was sunk by a mine off Folkestone.
A pleasure boat and former little ship of Dunkirk that collided with the dredger Bowbelle near Cannon Street railway bridge, with 51 deaths.
A French ship torpedoed by UB-40.
A brig that struck rocks at Rump Point.
A Tudor warship sunk in Portsmouth Harbour, possibly during an engagement with the French fleet. Now a protected wrecksite
A brig that became stranded in rough weather. Its crew were rescued by a lifeboat which subsequently took the name Mary White.
A troopship rammed by Darro, with the loss of 646 lives.
A merchant ship wrecked off Land's End in rough weather.
A merchant vessel that was stranded on the wreck of the SS Monte Nevoso at Haisborough Sands, and then bombed by German aircraft.
A barque wrecked off Peninnis Head.
A merchant vessel that ran aground on Haisborough Sands.
A transatlantic ocean liner, upon which the murderer Hawley Crippen was arrested while attempting to flee to Canada. The ship was wrecked when she broke loose from her moorings during a gale.
A merchant vessel that ran aground on Ower Bank.
A Polish ocean liner sunk off Grimsby.
A mini-bulk carrier that ran aground near Mousehole. It caused the Penlee lifeboat disaster.
A merchant vessel that ran aground off St Mary's.
A cargo ship that sank in the English Channel.
German cargo ship that ran ashore at Land's End. Five crew members were airlifted to safety.
A packet ship that ran aground on the Western Rocks.
A mail steamer that collided with the steamship Mary near The Needles.

Three mast Barque (Bark. Nor). Sailing from Brunswick Georgia to Bristol England. Forced ashore at Berrow beach, Somerset, by a storm. All crew and the ship's dog were rescued. The hull remains as a wreck on the beach to this day.
An American transatlantic ship that ran aground off Thanet.
A Blackwall Frigate that was rammed by a steamer while at anchor off Dungeness, resulting in the loss of 293 lives.
A Swiss cargo ship that ran aground at Berwickshire in 1958, but was salvaged and repaired. It sank for the final time off Beachy Head, following a collision.
A Swiss cargo ship that ran aground at Berwickshire in 1958, but was salvaged and repaired. It sank for the final time off Beachy Head, following a collision.
An ocean liner that hit a mine off South Shields.
A privateer that sank in the River Mersey.
A cargo ship that was sunk by mine off Aldeburgh.
A 1,028 GRT merchant vessel sank in heavy seas 6.6 nautical miles (12.2 km) SW from the Isle of Wight.
A five-masted windjammer that was rammed by SS Brighton, and subsequently driven onto rocks off the coast of Dover.
An Elizabethan wreck discovered in the Thames Estuary in 2004.
A paddle steamer that collided with Bywell Castle near North Woolwich, with over 650 deaths.
A passenger ship that was wrecked off the Eastern Isles.
A fishing vessel that struck rocks off Peninnis Head.
A cargo ship and mine carrier that was torpedoed by German submarine UC-17 off The Lizard.
A Liberty ship that ran aground off the Nore in the Thames Estuary with over a thousand tons of explosives on board. A protected wreck site, designated as dangerous.
A RO-RO ferry that ran aground on Blackpool beach and was finally scrapped in place after refloating attempts failed.
Struck a mine off Hastings.
Struck a mine off Hastings. Amsterdam 26 January 1749 A Dutch East India Company ship that ran aground near Hastings. The wreck site is protected.

A turret ship that collided with SMS König Wilhelm off Folkestone, resulting in 269 deaths.
A Königsberg-class cruiser that was scuttled in Scapa Flow in 1919, but was raised by Allied forces and ultimately sunk as a target.
A collier hit by bombs off Dartmouth; towed to Woodspring Bay, near Weston, for trials and target practice . The MOD base at St Thomas Head used the vessel for trials after WW2.

The SV Carl was impounded by British forces during the First World War and was suspected of being a minelayer. It was being towed to London when it ran aground on Booby's Bay.

A ship that was most likely carrying supplies to rebuild after the Great Fire of 1666.
These ships collided with each other. The Blackfriar III is the most complete medieval sailing ship found in Great Britain.
